Situation1: They briefly mention their day during a casual conversation at home.
Situation2: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, notes scattered, rehearsing the key points for tomorrow’s mentoring session. My mentee was counting on me to break down the new project workflow, and I knew how much they struggled with deadlines. I wanted to be thorough, to share every trick I’d learned, to make sure they felt supported and ready. Just as I was mapping out the session, my spouse walked in, setting down their bag with a tired sigh. “Today was rough,” they said, voice soft, almost lost in the hum of the fridge. I glanced up, catching the hint of something more behind their words. I knew I should ask, listen, open the door for them to share. That’s what we promised each other—honest, open communication, no matter how busy life got. But the clock was ticking, and my mind was tangled in deadlines and lesson plans. I felt the pull in both directions—my spouse needing my attention, my mentee needing my guidance. My heart ached with the weight of both expectations, torn between being present at home and being prepared for work.
